column4: U.S. defense firm joins creditors seeking to enforce Venezuela judgments
column5: (Reuters) - U.S. defense contractor Huntington Ingalls Industries Inc has joined a long line of creditors seeking to enforce a judgment against heavily indebted OPEC member Venezuela, court documents filed on Friday showed.
column6: Huntington Ingalls’ shipbuilding unit earlier this year received a $138 million judgment from a Mississippi court against Venezuela’s defense ministry over non-payment for repairs to two of the South American country’s warships which began decades ago.
column7: The repairs began before Washington-Caracas relations grew hostile, under late socialist President Hugo Chavez.
column8: Oil-rich Venezuela has suffered a six-year economic collapse under Nicolas Maduro, Chavez’ successor and mentee, and the government owes billions to creditors abroad.
column9: On Friday, Huntington Ingalls registered its Mississippi judgment in Delaware federal court and requested the case be assigned to a judge overseeing an effort by Canadian gold miner Crystallex to collect on debts owed by Venezuela by seizing a stake in the parent company of U.S. refiner Citgo Petroleum Corp, a unit of Venezuela’s state oil company PDVSA.
column10: “We anticipate that Ingalls will next file a Petition for a Writ of Attachment on Citgo parent PDV Holding and get in line,” Russ Dallen, managing partner of boutique investment bank Caracas Capital Markets, wrote in a note to clients.
column11: Neither Huntington Ingalls nor Venezuela’s information ministry immediately responded to requests for comment.
column12: To be sure, all companies are currently barred from seizing shares in PDV Holding, Citgo’s parent, due to U.S. sanctions aimed at ousting Maduro from power.
column13: That protection - part of an effort by the Trump administration to keep Citgo under the control of the Venezuelan opposition - expires in October, but it has previously been extended multiple times.
column14: PDVSA has also used shares in Citgo’s parent as collateral for its bonds maturing in 2020 and for a 2017 loan from Russian state oil company Rosneft.

column4: General Dynamics, Huntington Ingalls win $22 billion contract for U.S. submarines
column5: WASHINGTON (Reuters) - General Dynamics Corp GD.N was named lead contractor on a $22.2 billion U.S. Navy contract for the construction of nine Virginia-class submarines, the Pentagon said on Monday in announcing its largest-ever shipbuilding award.
column6: General Dynamics Electric Boat Corp is the prime contractor and Huntington Ingalls Industries Inc HII.N is a major subcontractor, the Pentagon said in a statement.
column7: Eighteen Virginia-class submarines have already been delivered to the Navy. The first ship of the nine new orders will be delivered in 2024. The Navy plans to buy 40 Virginia-class submarines.
column8: Construction of the submarines will be carried out at General Dynamics facilities in Connecticut and by Huntington Ingalls at its facilities in Virginia.
column9: Executives from both companies said they have been ramping up hiring and investing in facilities in anticipation of the award.
column10: Powered by small nuclear reactors, Virginia-class submarines can carry Mark 48 Advanced Capability torpedoes, unmanned underwater vehicles and Tomahawk land-attack missiles.

column4: General Dynamics, Huntington Ingalls win $22 bln contract for U.S. submarines
column5: WASHINGTON, Dec 2 (Reuters) - General Dynamics Corp has been awarded a $22.2 billion U.S. Navy contract for the construction of nine Virginia-class submarines, the Pentagon said on Monday in announcing its largest-ever shipbuilding award.
column6: General Dynamics Electric Boat Corp is the prime contractor and Huntington Ingalls Industries Inc is a major subcontractor, the Pentagon said in a statement. (Reporting by Eric Beech)

column4: Huntington among companies awarded U.S. government contract potentially valued at $17 billion
column5: (Reuters) - U.S. nuclear-powered ship maker Huntington Ingalls Industries HII.N said on Thursday it was among the 16 companies awarded an intelligence analysis contract by the U.S. government.
column6: The contract has a potential value of $17 billion and a base period of five years, the company said.
column7: Huntington will provide a wide range of analytic and operational support services to the U.S. Defense Intelligence Agency as part of the contract.
column8: The company's shares rose nearly 3% to $214.31 following the news. Up to Wednesday's close, the stock had risen 9.6% this year, underperforming a 21.4% increase in the Dow Jones U.S. Industrials index .DJUSIN.

column4: Huntington among companies awarded U.S. govt. contract valued at $17 bln
column5: Sept 5 (Reuters) - U.S. nuclear-powered ship maker Huntington Ingalls Industries said on Thursday it was among the 16 companies awarded an intelligence analysis contract by the U.S. government.
column6: The contract has a potential value of $17 billion and a base period of five years, the company said.
column7: Huntington will provide a wide range of analytic and operational support services to the U.S. Defense Intelligence Agency as part of the contract. (Reporting by Ankit Ajmera in Bengaluru; Editing by Maju Samuel)

column4: Huntington Ingalls wins $687 million U.S. defense contract: Pentagon
column5: WASHINGTON (Reuters) - Huntington Ingalls Industries Inc’s Newport News Shipbuilding division has been awarded a $687 million contract for work on the USS Gerald R. Ford aircraft carrier, the Pentagon said on Wednesday.

column4: Huntington Ingalls wins $1.47 bln U.S. defense contract -Pentagon
column5: WASHINGTON, March 26 (Reuters) - Huntington Ingalls Industries Inc has been awarded a $1.47 billion U.S. defense contract for construction of Landing Platform Dock 30, an amphibious warfare ship, the Pentagon said on Tuesday. (Reporting by Eric Beech; Editing by David Alexander)

column4: Huntington Ingalls wins $15 billion deal for two aircraft carriers
column5: WASHINGTON (Reuters) - The Pentagon said on Thursday it awarded Huntington Ingalls Industries Inc a $15.2 billion contract to build two nuclear-powered aircraft carriers.
column6: The U.S. Navy told lawmakers in December it intended to pursue a block purchase of two Ford-class aircraft carriers, a step officials have said could save billions of dollars as the Trump administration tries to expand the size of the fleet.
column7: The Navy commissioned the first Ford-class aircraft carrier, the USS Gerald R. Ford, in July 2017, three years behind schedule and billions of dollars over budget. The Ford cost about $13 billion.
column8: The ships, which will be built at the Newport News shipyard in Virginia, are scheduled to be delivered in 2028 and 2032, Huntington Ingalls said.
column9: The largest military shipbuilding company said the two-ship deal would save the Navy more than $4 billion.
column10: The Navy released a force structure goal in 2016 that calls for a 355-ship fleet. It previously it had a goal of 308 ships. The Navy currently has a fleet of 287 warships
column11: A 355-ship fleet would include 12 aircraft carriers, one more than the previous goal. The United States now operates 11 aircraft carriers, several times more than any other country.

column4: Huntington Ingalls wins U.S. defense contracts worth $15.2 bln -Pentagon
column5: WASHINGTON, Jan 31 (Reuters) - Huntington Ingalls Industries Inc has been awarded three U.S. defense contracts worth a total of $15.2 billion for construction of two nuclear-powered aircraft carriers, the Pentagon said on Thursday.

column4: Huntington Ingalls wins $5.1 billion U.S. defense contract: Pentagon
column5: WASHINGTON (Reuters) - Huntington Ingalls Industries HII.N has been awarded a $5.1 billion U.S. defense contract for the construction of six DDG 51 class ships, the Pentagon said on Thursday.
